resources.string: Between the peaks of Mt Taygetos and the gulf of Messinia, Kalamata dances to a different tune. Kalamata is Messinia’s capital and the second-largest city in the Peloponnese. /n Built on the site of ancient Pharai, Kalamata takes its modern name from a miracle-working icon of the Virgin Mary known as kalo mata (good eye).

The Old Town, the exquisite beautiful region at the foot of the Castle, boasts the Metropolitan Panagia Ipapanti church (1873), the 12th century Kalograion Monastery with the renowned silk weaving workshop, and the Byzantine church Agioi Apostoloi (13th century) with the brick enclosed masonry. The area is the hotspot for the city’s youth, for it is the beating heart of the nightlife in Kalamata and by no means will it be still!

Blowing the whistle on... The Railway Museum: One of Greece’s first theme parks, its steam locomotives, diesel engines, passenger and freight cars and two-storey central station building make it a treat for kids of ALL ages! \n All aboard for a ride into a bygone era.

The seaside road in front of the city’s extensive beach (4 km length with marvellous waters). On the seaside of Kalamata, people can swim in crystal clear waters and enjoy lace-like beaches, which have been granted the Blue Flag award of quality. Along the seaside, there are several tavernas, ouzo restaurants, cafeterias, bars, clubs, whereas beach aficionados can enjoy all kinds of water sports.

The spacious central Vassileos Georgiou (King George) square with many coffee shops, meeting places and strolling venues for residents and visitors. The pedestrian walkway of Aristomenous Street starts here with many stores and coffee shops to populate it.

The point of reference par excellence in the city of Kalamata is the legendary “castle of Isabeau”. It is amphitheatrically constructed on the site of the Farai acropolis offering a bird’s eye view of the city. Constructed in the 13th century by William Villehardouin, it underwent subsequent additions and conversions by the Venetians and the Turks. Nowadays, it is an ideal open air venue for theatre, music and dance shows.

This partially interactive, child-friendly museum focuses on treasures found in four regions – Kalamata, Pylia, Messini and Trifylia. Exhibits include everything from sculpture, pottery and funereal objects found in tholos (Mycenaean tombs shaped like a beehive) at Nestor's Palace, to Roman mosaics, gold jewellery and votive offerings. It provides wonderful context to the surrounding areas.

Opened in 2017, this stunning museum is thanks to one individual, Victoria Karelia, who donated her remarkable collection of Greek costumes to a group known as the "Lyceum of Hellenic Women of Kalamata". Far from moth-eaten old hand-me-downs, the clothing showcases male and female folk dress from the 18th to 20th centuries in beautifully curated, dramatically lit exhibits.

One of the most significant archaeological sites is Ancient Messene which is located just outside of Mavromati village, 30 km from the center of Kalamata. This is one of the most well-preserved ancient city in Greece, which to this day manages to maintain the prestige of yesteryear, leaving its visitors impressed. The city was named after the mythical Queen Messini, daughter of King Triopios of Argos. The city remained the cultural center of Messinia until 395, when the invasion of the Goths of Alaric gave the decisive blow to the city.

Built in 1209 by the Venetians, the castle of Methoni lies at the southernmost point of the Peloponnese and is one of the greatest fortifications in the Mediterranean, occupying an area of about 9.3 hectares.

Anyone that has heard of Mani brings to mind the impressive and imposing tower houses that have been taken out of the area\'s noble past and constructed with the traditional stone from Mani. West (Messinian) Mani belongs to Messinia. There you will observe these buildings, which are a representation and reflection of each family's power and status in society.

Rafting is an activity for all ages where everybody, given that they are physically and mentally healthy can participate. The activity includes a 45 minutes preparation time, 2.5 hours river descend, 30 minutes swimming, relaxing, The descents are performed if the conditions (river level) are proper.
Dive into a magical world with almost zero gravity, where you will encounter a breathtaking seabed that will impress you with abundant colors and unique inhabitants.

Explore the town of Kalamata on a bike. Opt for this means of transport to wander around the beach, the town center and the town\'s historical center, following in the locals\' footsteps. Get a bike then and scour every corner of the Messinian capital. You should know that Kalamata has a developed bicycle network, so getting around on a bike will be safe.

Sea kayaking is indeed one of our most popular trips offering an inch by inch exploration of the rich in imagery and diversity, lacy coastline of the Messinian Mani. Paddle in warm crystal-clear waters, exploring hidden coves and impressive rock formations. Visit sea caves and discover idyllic beaches sprouted between the fishing villages of the region.

Escape from the everyday routine and spend your free time visiting the facilities of the Kalamata Riding Club, in the city\'s west coast. It is a modern riding school operated in accordance with European standards and offers basic, sports, free-style, therapeutic riding lesson and it also provides lairage for private horses.

The Hellenic Mountaineering Club of Kalamata has been operating since 1993 and organizes various hiking, mountain climbing, rock climbing and ascents on a weekly basis. As a member of the Hellenic Federation of Mountaineering and Climbing it has been approved by the General Secretariat of Sports and has taken the initiative to promote the ecosystem of Mt. Taygetos to that of a National Park. In this natural setting, will learn to love nature during your stay in Kalamata and the wider area.
The war of darts (saitopolemos), which takes us back many centuries, is revived every Easter Sunday evening at 20.30 at the old Slaughterhouses on the west coast of Kalamata.

Established in 1995, the Kalamata International Dance Festival constitutes the key event of Kalamata\'s International Dance Center. Its purpose is to promote the art of dance through research, education, artistic activities and creativity.

Festival Miden was the first Greek video art festival to be presented in open public spaces in 2005. Since then it has been gradually established as one of the most successful and interesting festivals in Greece and abroad and constitutes a significant attraction of cultural interest. The events take place in open public spaces in Kalamata\'s historical center in July and the main purpose of the festival is the free presentation, promotion and development of Greek and international video art and new media art.

Try the “guru” of figs in Kalamata and taste the ancient athletes’ “drug”. It’s a dried fruit with a heap of vitamins and once you’ve had it, it’s going to become your healthy lifestyle companion for life.

These tiny olives are the ambassadors of Messenia and they are considered to be the world\'s best. They are handpicked during harvest and this is why they preserve the top quality taste and nutritive you’re looking for in your diet.

If you like feta cheese, then you should try the saltier member of this cheese family. It’s called Sfela and its nickname is “the feta that’s on fire”. Sfela is a traditional product of Messenia that’s produced from sheep and goat milk, with no other substances or enhancers.

Discover an artisan form of sausage that’s made with love in Kalamata. It has a very interesting taste, which is based on its spicy red peppers that are cooled down a bit by the refreshing orange slices.
The lalaggia are the main festive sweet that is prepared and offered during the Christmas period in Messinia.

Diples is a popular dessert in the whole of the Peloponnese, but the Kalamata version has an extra twist. The talented women of the region thought of adding some refreshing orange zest, which makes a yummy difference.
